name: dd
description: Creates bit-by-bit forensic disk images with precise sector copying
explain: The dd command is fundamental for forensic acquisitions, creating exact binary copies of storage devices. It operates at the sector level, ensuring complete data preservation including deleted files and slack space. Always verify with cryptographic hashes. Warning: dd can overwrite data if source/destination are reversed—use with extreme caution.

name: ewfacquire
description: Creates Expert Witness Format (E01) disk images with compression and metadata
output_example:
Acquired 500 GB in 3h 42m
Compression: 38% (310 GB output)
MD5/SHA1 verified
Case: 2024-INV-001
explain: EWF format (E01) is industry standard for forensic imaging, supporting compression, encryption, and embedded case metadata. Unlike raw dd images, E01 files include hash verification in segments, making them court-admissible and easier to manage. Always document chain of custody in metadata fields.

name: volatility
description: Extracts processes, network connections, registry hives, and malware from RAM dumps
output_example:
PID 4921: svchost.exe [HIDDEN]
Code injection detected
C2 connection: 203.0.113.87:4444
12 suspicious DLLs loaded
explain: Volatility is the gold standard for memory forensics, revealing runtime state invisible to disk analysis. It detects rootkits, recovers encryption keys, and reconstructs attacker actions from volatile memory. Requires correct OS profile matching. Critical for incident response as memory preserves evidence lost after shutdown.

name: rekall
description: Advanced memory forensics with live system analysis and cross-platform support
output_example:
Live acquisition: 16GB RAM
47 processes enumerated
Kernel modules: 3 unsigned
Network artifacts extracted
explain: Rekall extends memory analysis beyond static dumps, supporting live forensics on running systems. It's particularly effective for kernel-level malware detection and cross-platform investigations (Windows/Linux/macOS). Use for scenarios where traditional forensics would alert attackers or when time-critical evidence exists only in RAM.

name: tcpdump
description: Captures and analyzes network packets for traffic reconstruction
output_example:
15:42:18.234 IP 192.168.1.5.443 > 203.0.113.87.4444: Flags [P.], seq 1:1024
2847 packets captured
124 MB written to capture.pcap
explain: Tcpdump is essential for network forensics, capturing packet-level data for reconstruction of network activity. Use BPF filters to target specific traffic (e.g., 'tcp port 443'). Always capture to file for detailed analysis with Wireshark later. Note: Encrypted traffic (TLS/SSL) requires key material for decryption.

name: wireshark
description: GUI-based deep packet inspection and protocol analysis
output_example:
HTTP POST detected: 14.7 GB payload
Destination: suspicious-domain.com
Files extracted: 847 items
Malware signatures: 3 matches
explain: Wireshark provides visual protocol dissection, following TCP streams and extracting transferred files from packet captures. Critical for analyzing C2 communications, data exfiltration, and network-based attacks. Use display filters (not capture filters) for post-capture analysis. Export objects feature recovers files transmitted over HTTP/FTP.

name: ngrep
description: Network grep for pattern matching in packet payloads
output_example:
Match found: 'password='
T 192.168.1.5:51234 -> 10.0.0.1:80 [AP]
POST /login HTTP/1.1
password=admin123
explain: Ngrep applies regex pattern matching to network traffic, ideal for finding credentials, API keys, or specific strings in unencrypted communications. Unlike Wireshark, it's optimized for keyword searching across large captures. Use during incident response to quickly identify data leaks or credential transmission.

name: netstat
description: Displays active network connections and listening ports on live systems
output_example:
TCP 192.168.1.5:443 203.0.113.87:4444 ESTABLISHED 4921/svchost.exe
TCP 0.0.0.0:445 LISTENING 4/System
12 active connections
explain: Netstat reveals real-time network activity, crucial for identifying active malware connections or backdoors during incident response. The -anob flags show addresses, ports, owning processes, and disable name resolution. Document all suspicious connections immediately—they're volatile and lost at reboot.

name: zeek
description: Network security monitoring framework generating high-level logs from packets
output_example:
conn.log: 15847 connections analyzed
http.log: 2847 HTTP transactions
files.log: 234 transferred files
DNS beaconing detected
explain: Zeek (formerly Bro) transforms raw packets into structured logs, ideal for large-scale network forensics. It automatically extracts files, detects anomalies, and generates protocol-specific logs. Unlike Wireshark, Zeek handles terabyte-scale captures efficiently. Use for retrospective analysis of long-duration attacks or data exfiltration campaigns.

name: evtxdump
description: Parses Windows Event Logs (EVTX) for security events and system changes
output_example:
Event 4624: Successful logon
User: admin | Time: 02:34:17
Logon Type: 10 (RemoteInteractive)
234 failed logon attempts from 203.0.113.87
explain: Windows Event Logs document authentication, privilege changes, service installations, and scheduled tasks—critical for timeline reconstruction. Event ID 4624/4625 track successful/failed logons; 4688 shows process creation; 7045 indicates service installation (common persistence). Parse offline to avoid alerting active attackers.

name: syslog
description: Analyzes Unix/Linux system logs for authentication and system events
output_example:
/var/log/auth.log: 847 SSH attempts
Failed password for root from 203.0.113.87
Successful sudo: user executed /bin/bash
Cron job created: suspicious script
explain: Linux/Unix syslog files (auth.log, syslog, kern.log) track user activity, failed authentications, and system events. Critical for detecting unauthorized access, privilege escalation, and persistence mechanisms. Check /var/log/ for rotated logs (auth.log.1, .2.gz). Parse chronologically for attack timeline reconstruction.

name: chainsaw
description: Rapid Windows Event Log analysis with threat hunting rules
output_example:
Sigma rule matched: Mimikatz execution
Event 4688: lsass.exe accessed by powershell.exe
3 suspicious process creations
Timeline: 02:34-02:47 (13 min window)
explain: Chainsaw accelerates Windows Event Log analysis by applying SIGMA detection rules, identifying malicious patterns like credential dumping, lateral movement, and persistence. It's optimized for speed across large log sets. Use during incident response to quickly identify attacker TTPs without manual log review.

name: regedit
description: Parses Windows Registry hives for user activity and system configuration
output_example:
NTUSER.DAT parsed
Recent Documents: 234 files
USB History: SanDisk 128GB (Last: 12:15:47)
Run Key: C:\malware.exe
explain: Windows Registry stores critical forensic artifacts: recent files (RecentDocs), USB devices (USBSTOR), program execution (UserAssist), and persistence (Run keys). Parse offline hives (NTUSER.DAT, SYSTEM, SOFTWARE) to avoid detection. Always check HKCU/HKLM Run keys for malware auto-start. Timestamps reveal user behavior timeline.

name: regripper
description: Automated Windows Registry parsing with forensic-focused plugins
output_example:
ShellBags: User accessed C:\Confidential\
UserAssist: program.exe run 47 times
RecentDocs: 234 files in last 7 days
Network history: 5 WiFi networks
explain: RegRipper automates registry artifact extraction with specialized plugins for forensic artifacts like ShellBags (folder access), UserAssist (program execution counts), and typed URLs. It's faster than manual analysis and ensures no artifacts are missed. Critical for Windows timeline reconstruction and user profiling.

name: shimcache
description: Parses Application Compatibility Cache for program execution evidence
output_example:
C:\malware.exe | Last Modified: 2024-11-25 18:34
C:\Users\Admin\Downloads\tool.exe
847 cached executables found
explain: ShimCache (AppCompatCache) records all executables run on Windows, including path and last modification time. Unlike Prefetch, it doesn't prove execution time but confirms file presence. Useful when Prefetch is disabled/deleted. Located in SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Session Manager\AppCompatCache. Parse for malware that executed but left no other traces.
